pageContext.claim: “They [Japan] send us millions and millions of cars; they have for many years. They're essentially not taxed. So they send them in from Japan. They're essentially not taxed. … Essentially, it's 2.5 percent, but there's ways of getting around it. Essentially, non-tariff, free.”
pageContext.analysis: Japanese officials say the 2.5 percent tariff is significant. In their negotiations over a new trade deal, the Japanese tried unsuccessfully to get the U.S. tariff removed. Trump's claim that Japan sends millions of cars a year is suspect. Japanese automakers have U.S. plants, which produce more than half of the cars sold in the United States. When counting free-trade partners Canada and Mexico nearly three-quarters of Japanese cars sold in the U.S. are made in North America.
